did.unittitle: Indiana University Institute for Urban Transportation records

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Indiana University, Bloomington. Institute for Urban Transportation

did.abstract: The Institute for Urban Transportation was founded in 1969 by Dr. George M. Smerk, a professor of transportation at Indiana University's School of Business (renamed the Kelley School of Business in 1997). The institute aimed to improve public transportation management and policy through education, research, and technical assistance. The collection includes materials published by the institute, including technical handbooks, a newsletter, and reports generated from the institute's consultation studies with various public transportation departments in Indiana and the surrounding states. The collection also includes materials from public transportation-related conferences and workshops conducted in the 1980s and 1990s, as well as administrative files.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Advance notice required.

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: The Institute for Urban Transportation was founded in 1969 by Dr. George M. Smerk, a professor of transportation at Indiana University's School of Business (renamed the Kelley School of Business in 1997). The institute aimed to improve public transportation management and policy through education, research, and technical assistance. The institute published practical handbooks such as Mass Transit Management: A Handbook for Small Cities (1971) and the Handbook for Management Performance Audits (1979). In 1975, the institute was designated Indiana's first state agency for mass transit under the Indiana Mass Transportation Improvement Project. Dr. Smerk and geography professor William R. Black wrote the City of Bloomington Mass Transportation Technical Study in 1973, establishing the routes and schedules for the first public transportation system in Bloomington, Indiana. During this period, the institute also developed the Management Performance Audit (MPA) procedures and conducted more than a dozen audits throughout the Midwest. In 1979, the institute was awarded the Administrator's Award from the Urban Mass Transportation Administration, a division of the federal Department of Transportation. The award recognized the institute for developing innovative transportation services and management techniques for the state of Indiana.

Dr. Smerk served as the director of the institute until his retirement from Indiana University in 2003. Kent McDaniel, a former student of Dr. Smerk's who became Indiana University's transportation liaison and a prominent figure in Indiana public transportation development, also had a prominent role at the Institute for Urban Transportation. He spent many years serving as the assistant director of the institute, a position he held until the institute closed in 2005 after 36 years of service.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into five series: Studies, Handbooks, Newsletter, Conference and Workshop Materials, and Administrative Files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Institute of Urban Transportation records consist primarily of the various studies and publications produced by the institute between 1971 and 1991. It also includes materials from conferences and workshops conducted from 1984 to 1992 on topics related to public transportation as well as administrative files from the institute's office. Among the publications are reports and studies stemming from the institute's consulting projects to develop and improve public transit systems in various cities across Indiana and the surrounding states. Also included in the collection are practical handbooks published by the institute in the 1970s and 1980s on topics related to public transit work, as well as a newsletter, titled That's About I.T. and then renamed Indiana Transit, which was published by the institute from 1977 to 1982.

The Administrative Files series includes a number of folders containing information about the history and development of the public bus system in Bloomington, Indiana, which began operations in the mid-1970s. The series also includes numerous newspaper clippings and other files related to the history and operations of the Institute for Urban Transportation during the course of its 36-year run.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional records such as newsletters, annual reports, bulletins, and publications may be accessed in the Archives of Institutional Memory.
Related photographs may be available in the Indiana University Archives Photograph Collection.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright interests for this collection have been transferred to the Trustees of Indiana University. For more information, contact the Indiana University Archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Indiana University Institute for Urban Transportation records, Collection C682, Indiana University Archives, Bloomington.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The materials in this collection were transferred to the Archives from the Institute for Urban Transportation and the Kelley School of Business in three accessions. The first accession was transferred in August 2005, and the second and third were transferred in August 2016.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The Studies series is arranged into eleven subseries: Development studies, Feasibility studies, Funding studies, Maintenance plans, Marketing plans, Management and performance assessments, Planning assistance, Rail plans, Transit evaluation programs, Transportation and technical studies, and Indiana transportation inventories and directories. Each subseries is arranged alphabetically by title.
